artist: Artist: Master of the Horse Heads, Netherlandish
creditline: Gift of Elizabeth, Julie, and Catherine Andrus in memory of John and Marion Andrus
description: decorative pattern: two winged nude female figures with animal-like lower bodies flanking a vertical stem at center; each holds a twisted frond that curls, and swirls into larger leaf pattern
inscription:
Stamp, Label

-- label on mat: Kennedy Galleries, 40 W. 57th St., 5th Floor, N.Y., 10019 / 212-541-9600 / Stock no. 114759.0001 | Number 19293 / 130204
-- in graphite on verso: HB XI IX IV | XP.157.27 | B.27 | a14759 | IK(boxed)  
-- in red chalk on verso: [line bisected by a perpendicular line]
markings: black stamp on verso, UL: Albertina duplicate, Lugt 5h; black stamp on verso, UC: Albertina, Lugt 5e; Kennedy Galleries label
provenance: Albertina, Vienna, duplicate, Lugt 5h and Lugt 5e. [Kennedy Galleries, New York; sold to Andrus]; John E. Andrus III, Wayzata, Minn.; by descent to his daughters, Elizabeth, Katie, and Julie; gave to MIA, 2015. Earlier provenances have been gathered, but further research will increase our knowledge of their histories.
text: Ornament designers hit the motherlode when Emperor Nero’s ancient villa was excavated in Rome in about 1480. A profusion of strange hybrid creatures was found frescoed on underground spaces, or grottos—hence the name grotesques. These fabulous creatures migrated north and inspired this furry-legged nude by Master of the Horse Heads, an unidentified Dutch printmaker known by his horse imagery.
title: Ornament with Two Winged Female Half-Length Figures
